document_title: Draft Genome Sequences from a Novel Clade of Bacillus cereus Sensu Lato Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station
summary_full: This paper presents the draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). These strains belong to the Bacillus anthracis-B. cereus-B. thuringiensis group and were isolated from different modules of the ISS. Four of the strains were sequenced using both Illumina MiSeq and PacBio RSII platforms, while the remaining two were sequenced using only Illumina MiSeq. The genomes were assembled using IDBA-UD and SPAdes, with IDBA-UD selected as the best assembly. Low confidence bases were masked, and PacBio assemblies were polished with Quiver and Pilon. Comparative genomic analysis showed high similarity among the ISS isolates and to members of the B. cereus sensu lato group. Notably, these isolates lack key pathogenicity elements of B. anthracis, including the pXO1 and pXO2 plasmids, and possess the ancestral "C" allele of the plcR gene, placing them phylogenetically outside the B. anthracis clade. The collective genomic evidence supports the conclusion that these six ISS isolates represent a novel Bacillus sp. within the B. cereus sensu lato group.
key_findings: Draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains isolated from the International Space Station were generated.
These strains belong to the Bacillus cereus sensu lato group and exhibit high genomic similarity to each other.
The ISS isolates lack key pathogenicity elements of Bacillus anthracis, including pXO1 and pXO2 plasmids.
Phylogenetic analysis places these novel strains outside the B. anthracis clade.
The strains possess the ancestral 'C' allele of the plcR gene, a distinguishing marker within the B. cereus group.
future_research_fields: Further characterization of the novel Bacillus clade's ecological role and potential adaptations to the space environment.
Investigation into the specific evolutionary pressures that led to the divergence of these strains from known B. cereus group members.
Comparative studies on the metabolic capabilities and stress resistance of these ISS isolates compared to terrestrial counterparts.
Exploration of potential biotechnological applications of these unique microbial isolates.

conclusions: The six Bacillus strains isolated from the ISS represent a novel clade within the B. cereus sensu lato group. Their genomic analysis indicates they are distinct from B. anthracis, lacking its characteristic virulence plasmids and possessing an ancestral plcR allele. This suggests a unique evolutionary trajectory for these space-borne bacteria.
impact_statement: This study provides the first genomic insights into a novel Bacillus clade discovered on the ISS, contributing to our understanding of microbial adaptation in extreme environments and informing biosecurity protocols for space exploration.
